title: How to build a team that can “take a punch” | Hilary Gridley (Head of Core Product, Whoop)
themes: self care and work life balance
key_insights: When facing criticism or setbacks, focus on actions that demonstrate the opposite of what you fear others think about you rather than trying to argue or explain
Understanding how key stakeholders think is more valuable than knowing what they think - build mental models of their decision making frameworks
Use 'magic questions' (statements ending with 'do you agree?' or 'is that right?') to quickly understand another person's mental model
Create habit formation through consistency, reduced friction, and powerful immediate emotional rewards
AI can dramatically accelerate learning by providing on demand feedback and unlimited practice opportunities
Product leaders should focus on operationalizing the CEO's vision rather than trying to impose their own
Behavioral activation (taking action to improve mood) is more effective than waiting to feel better before acting
Reward loops need to be powerful, immediate, and emotional to drive lasting behavior change

guest_background.current_role: Head of Core Product at Whoop

topics_discussed: Building teams that can handle adversity and setbacks
Counter programming narratives when facing criticism
Understanding stakeholder mental models and decision making frameworks
Using AI for accelerated learning and skill development
Habit formation principles in product design and team management
Behavioral activation techniques from cognitive behavioral therapy
The relationship between product leaders and CEO vision
Creating space for creativity and self care as a leader
Whoop 5.0 product launch and new health features
Using reward loops to drive user behavior change
Magic questions technique for understanding others
Building AI powered learning tools and GPTs
Balancing obsession with responsibility in product work
The importance of fiction reading for developing empathy and perspective
memorable_quotes: Product leadership is the type of role where if you are not in control of the voices in your head, they will eat you alive.
What is the action that you can take to counter program the narrative that you are afraid that this other person has of you?
You're not special. In the story of work, you are probably not the protagonist.
recommended_for: anyone managing teams through difficult challenges
summary: Hilary Gridley shares practical frameworks for building resilient teams that can handle adversity, including techniques from behavioral psychology for 'taking punches' and bouncing back from setbacks. She emphasizes understanding stakeholder mental models, using AI for accelerated learning, and the importance of self care in sustaining high performance leadership.
